docs.title: Step 1: Data Loading & Preparation
docs.text:
• Load Brent oil prices CSV (1987-2022)
  • Convert Date column to datetime format
  • Handle missing values with interpolation
  • Check for data quality issues

docs.title: Step 2: Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA)
docs.text:
• Plot raw price series over time
  • Calculate daily returns and log returns
  • Test for stationarity using Augmented Dickey-Fuller test
  • Analyze volatility patterns and clustering
  • Create summary statistics

docs.title: Step 3: Event Research & Compilation
docs.text:
• Research historical events affecting oil prices (already done)
  • 25 events compiled in CSV file
  • Categorize events: Conflicts, Economic Crises, OPEC Decisions, Supply/Demand Shocks

docs.title: Step 4: Bayesian Change Point Modeling
docs.text:
• Implement Bayesian model using PyMC
  • Define priors: change point location, means before/after, standard deviations
  • Run MCMC sampling (NUTS algorithm)
  • Check convergence using R-hat statistics and trace plots

docs.title: Step 5: Results Interpretation
docs.text:
• Extract posterior distributions of change points
  • Identify most probable change dates
  • Match change points with historical events
  • Quantify impact: mean change, volatility change, percentage impact

docs.title: Step 6: Communication & Visualization
docs.text:
• Create interactive dashboard (Flask + React)
  • Generate technical report with findings
  • Prepare executive summary for stakeholders

docs.title: Assumptions:
docs.text:
1. Market Efficiency: Oil prices quickly incorporate new information
  2. Data Quality: Historical price data is accurate and complete
  3. Immediate Impact: Events have immediate or near-immediate effects
  4. Model Specification: Normal distribution adequately models price changes
  5. Representativeness: Brent prices reflect global oil market dynamics

docs.title: Limitations:
docs.text:
1. Correlation ≠ Causation:
  2. Just because a price change occurs after an event doesn't prove the event caused it
  3. Other factors could be responsible

  4. We identify statistical associations, not definitive causal relationships

  5. Multiple Confounding Factors:

  6. Events often occur simultaneously

  7. Global economic conditions, currency fluctuations, alternative energy developments

  8. Model Limitations:

  9. Single change point model may oversimplify
  10. Assumes abrupt changes (not gradual)

  11. May miss small but important changes

  12. Data Limitations:

  13. Daily data may miss intra-day reactions
  14. Only considers price, not volume or other market indicators

docs.title: Key Properties to Analyze:
docs.text:
1. Trend: Long-term upward/downward movement in prices
  2. Stationarity: Whether statistical properties change over time
  3. Volatility: How much prices fluctuate
  4. Seasonality: Regular repeating patterns
  5. Autocorrelation: Relationship between current and past values

docs.title: How This Informs Modeling:
docs.text:
• Non-stationary data → Use differencing or log returns
  • High volatility → Consider volatility models (GARCH)
  • Autocorrelation → Include lag terms if needed
  • Non-normal returns → Consider alternative distributions

docs.title: Purpose:
docs.text: Identify points in time when the statistical properties of a time series change significantly.

docs.title: How They Help:
docs.text:
1. Detect Structural Breaks: Find when market "regimes" change
  2. Quantify Changes: Measure how much parameters changed
  3. Associate with Events: Match changes with historical events
  4. Provide Probabilistic Estimates: Give confidence intervals, not just point estimates

docs.title: Expected Outputs:
docs.text:
1. Change Point Dates: Most probable dates when changes occurred
  2. Parameter Estimates: Means and volatilities before/after changes
  3. Impact Quantification: "Price increased by X% with Y% probability"
  4. Uncertainty Measures: Confidence intervals, posterior distributions

docs.title: Model Limitations:
docs.text:
1. Assumes changes are abrupt
  2. May require specifying number of change points
  3. Sensitive to model specification
  4. Requires sufficient data between change points

docs.title: Key Assumptions:
docs.text:
1. Market Efficiency Assumption: Oil prices reflect all available information at time t
  2. Exogeneity Assumption: Events are external shocks to the market
  3. Structural Break Assumption: Price dynamics change abruptly at detected points
  4. Data Quality Assumption: Historical data is accurate and representative
  5. Model Specification: Normal distribution adequately captures price returns

docs.title: Important Limitations:
docs.text:
1. Causality vs Correlation:
  2. Critical Limitation: Detected change points may correlate with but not necessarily be caused by listed events
  3. Example: A change point might coincide with an event but be driven by unobserved factors

  4. Mitigation: Use event windows and control for other known factors

  5. Multiple Simultaneous Events:

  6. Events often cluster in time (e.g., 2008 financial crisis with OPEC decisions)
  7. Attribution of price changes to specific events is challenging

  8. Approach: Use Bayesian model averaging to assess probabilities

  9. Market Anticipation Effects:

  10. Prices may adjust before official event dates (e.g., sanctions announcements)
  11. Impact: Change points may precede actual event dates

  12. Solution: Include announcement dates where available

  13. Model Simplifications:

  14. Single change point model may miss multiple regime shifts
  15. Normal distribution may not capture fat tails in oil returns

  16. Plan: Extend to multiple change points and student-t distributions

  17. Time Lag Considerations:

  18. Event impacts may unfold over days/weeks, not instantaneously

  19. Approach: Analyze event windows (±30 days) rather than single dates

  20. Confounding Variables:

  21. Macroeconomic factors (GDP, inflation, USD strength)
  22. Technological changes (shale revolution)
  23. Acknowledgment: These are not explicitly modeled in initial analysis

docs.title: Technical Risks:
docs.text:
1. Computational Intensity: MCMC sampling for long time series

  2. Mitigation: Use efficient sampling, reduce tuning steps initially

  3. Model Convergence: Poor mixing or non-convergence

  4. Mitigation: Multiple chains, extensive diagnostics, parameter tuning

  5. Data Quality Issues: Gaps or anomalies in price data

  6. Mitigation: Robust interpolation, outlier detection
